summary: This is a declaration by David Rodgers, a former pilot for Jeffrey Epstein, submitted in response to a subpoena in a civil lawsuit (Jane Doe v. Darren Indyke, et al.). Rodgers provides his flight logs from 1994-1997 and describes his record-keeping practices, noting the appearance of two specific names in the logs, though he has no specific recollection of the flights.

persons.name: David Rodgers
persons.context: Submits this declaration in response to a subpoena. He worked as a pilot for Jeffrey Epstein and Epstein-affiliated entities beginning in 1991 and provides his flight logs from 1994-1997.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'Mr. Jeffrey Epstein.' David Rodgers worked as a pilot for him and Epstein-affiliated entities beginning in 1991.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.context: Named as a defendant in the civil lawsuit 'Jane Doe v. Darren Indyke, et al.' This declaration is part of that case.

persons.name: Jane Doe
persons.context: Named as the plaintiff in the civil lawsuit 'Jane Doe v. Darren Indyke, et al.' The subpoena prompting this declaration was issued by the plaintiff.

connections.description: Rodgers worked as a pilot for Epstein and Epstein-affiliated entities beginning in 1991.
Rodgers is responding to a subpoena from the plaintiff, Jane Doe, in a civil lawsuit.

events.title: Subpoena Issued to David Rodgers
events.description: The plaintiff, Jane Doe, issued a subpoena to David Rodgers directing him to produce documents and appear for a deposition.

events.title: Execution of Declaration
events.description: David Rodgers executed this declaration under penalty of perjury, submitting it in lieu of appearing for a deposition.

events.title: Flight Log Period
events.description: The period covered by the flight logs attached to the declaration, during which Rodgers regularly recorded passenger information.

keyFacts: David Rodgers, a pilot for Jeffrey Epstein since 1991, submitted flight logs from 1994-1997 as part of a civil lawsuit.
Rodgers' practice was to record passenger names in the flight log's 'Remarks' column if he knew or learned them, otherwise using generic descriptions like '1 Female'.
The declaration notes the first appearance of two specific names in the flight logs, but Rodgers states he has no specific recollection of those flights from over 23 years ago.
The document is subject to a protective order limiting the disclosure of certain paragraphs (7, 8, 9, 10, 15, and 17).
